In Germany they usually talk about the opposite.
@AnnaMelitta Das geht mit Datenansichten: https://t.co/KuJxmIUabI ‚Ä¶ allerdings erfasst das dann nur neuen Traffic.
@AnnaMelitta Besser w√§re es nat√ºrlich, wenn der Tracking-Code nicht auf preview l√§uft.
@benjamin I only thought about it from the customer perspective, it shows that they understand the importance of supporting great UX.
@benjamin How is it affecting net-neutrality? They are just not metering some traffic in their net.
@benjamin And traffic shaping has been done by telcos for ages.
@benjamin from their PoV it would be better to have NN, because now they will pay more for traffic, and carriers will charge them.
@benjamin In an NGN pokemon traffic could be charged extra by the backbones and T would have to pay actually more.
@benjamin Yes, they do. But I think there are good reasons to do this. e.g. you will want to guarantee resources for emergency numbers.
@MattBolton365 @vodafone_de @MarshGlobal In Germany, the customer works for the service.

Praktikum != Job ‚Ä¶

@benjamin you can't blame a company for doing that. It's a smart marketing stunt and I like the mindset. Cater towards experience.

@benjamin I thought of another example, in the DDR the distribution of goods was done via a NN, you would get what you needed to survive,
@benjamin but everything extra was either very expensive or you had to wait years. A Trabbi is a Netflix TV Show. You could watch one ep/mo.
@benjamin there was no economical advantage for producers to change this because their output (bread&Trabbis / WWW&PokemonGo) was regulated
@benjamin so, if it wasn't for discriminating business applications, we wouldn't have the powerful internet we have today.
@benjamin I believe in the future we'll see an open-net movement, where companies and individuals sponsor the free access to internet srvcs.
@benjamin not like Facebook does with its horrible https://t.co/NcnxfNmYL9 but like GitHub. And if you look at some developments around
@benjamin anonymous internet access, there will always be ways to enable free access to unpopular opinions.
